entry.title: Civ Kit: A Peer-to-Peer Electronic Market System
entry.summary: The conversation discussed the design assumptions and concerns surrounding front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace. Mary, Terry, and Bob were mentioned as participants in this discussion. Mary published a limit order to buy a derivative, and Bob had the option to execute the order or relay it to Terry. The concern raised was that Bob, as the bulletin board operator, could collect outsized profits, potentially causing Terry to move to other markets. It was suggested that Terry should open his own brokerage and compete with Bob on quoting prices.One solution proposed to mitigate front-running was to have multiple bulletin boards operated by independent identities. By monitoring the latency of these boards, anomalies could be identified and addressed. Another approach discussed was running the bulletin boards as a federation, using techniques like Honey Badger BFT, where consensus among federation members would be required before publishing offers.The importance of execution quality and providing better prices was emphasized, as it attracted more market activity. The concept of front-running resistance in different types of trades was explored, with some goods being considered less risky due to factors like production cycles. However, for fiat currencies or bitcoin financial contracts, front-running by the bulletin board remained a qualified concern.Different security paradigms were discussed, such as duplicating the announcement of offers to multiple boards and monitoring latency, or running the boards as a federation with consensus rules. The configuration of these parameters depended on real-world deployments and the types of trades involved.The conversation concluded by mentioning the CivKit framework, which aims to provide a flexible framework for peer-to-peer marketplaces. It highlighted the importance of adapting front-running resistance parameters to different types of trades and market participants' tolerance. Overall, the discussion provided insights into the design assumptions, concerns, and possible solutions regarding front-running in a peer-to-peer marketplace.In a recent email to the Lightning Dev mailing list, the authors of a paper shared their deep analysis of the system's architecture. They expressed gratitude to the peer reviewers for their contributions and mentioned plans to release code and modules gradually. Their goal was to adhere to Bitcoin's open-source and decentralized standards as established by Bitcoin Core. The authors emphasized their eagerness to collaborate with the community to standardize libraries and ensure long-term interoperability between clients.The email invited feedback from the community and was signed off by Nick, Ray, and Antoine, the authors of the paper. Several links were provided for reference, including one to the paper's content on GitHub, offering detailed insights into the system's architecture. Another link directed readers to the W3C Recommendation for DID (Decentralized Identifier) Core. A third link pointed to the Privacypass website, providing additional information on privacy-preserving technology. Lastly, a fourth link introduced the Lightning Dev Kit, which the authors planned to extensively build upon.Overall, the email served as an invitation to engage with the authors and contribute to the development and standardization efforts of the system. Feedback and collaboration from the community were highly encouraged.
